title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program includes authorized activities to support these students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need for specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. It acknowledges that these students have already mastered a significant portion of the school curriculum before the school year begins. Many teachers receive training to meet the needs of diverse students, but often lack training for gifted and talented students. High-ability students, especially those from inner cities, may not have access to private programs to supplement their education. Gifted education programs in public schools are essential for providing equal opportunities to high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Parents and families play a crucial role in supporting the educational needs of gifted students. There is currently no federal requirement for identifying gifted students. To address the disparity in resources and services for gifted students, it is crucial to establish federal requirements and consistent support at the state and local levels. This will ensure that all gifted and talented students have access to appropriate education to meet future economic and national security needs. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the United States on international assessments was among the lowest in the world, highlighting the lack of challenging programming for gifted students in the country. The United States lacks challenging programming for gifted students, leading to poor performance on international assessments. The Secretary may award competitive grants to State educational agencies for developing gifted education programs if the appropriated amount exceeds $7,500,000. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to enable them to provide gifted and talented education programs and materials to local educational agencies. Grant funds can be used for various activities, including providing direct educational services to gifted students. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for direct educational services for gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. A State educational agency receiving a grant under this chapter can use up to 10% of the funds for dissemination of program information, technical assistance, monitoring, parental education support, and creating a gifted education advisory board. Administrative costs cannot exceed 50% of the funds. A State educational agency can use up to 50% of the funds for administrative costs when receiving a grant under this chapter. SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES. From the amount available for this chapter, the Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining amount is allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. No state may receive less than half of one percent. The Secretary reserves funds for programs in Bureau of Indian Affairs schools from the available amount. States receive allotments based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17, with no state receiving less than half of one percent. If a state does not apply for an allotment, the Secretary will reallot the amount to other states. State application for funds is outlined in SEC. 5467B, with states receiving allotments based on population of individuals aged 5 through 17. If a state does not apply, the Secretary will reallot the funds to other states. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with specified assurances, including using funds to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, making grants to local educational agencies, and ensuring funds are used appropriately. The State educational agency must use grant funds to supplement local educational agencies for gifted and talented students, provide matching funds of at least 10%, and implement program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. Implement program assessment models for accountability and educational effectiveness. The Secretary will approve State applications that meet the requirements of this section. SEC. 5467C of the chapter mandates that State educational agencies allocate at least 90 percent of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for authorized activities. Grants must meet the needs of the students served. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to use the funds for this purpose. The local educational agency must ensure that funds received will supplement, not replace, the amount spent on education and related services for gifted and talented students. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act. Recipients of funds can serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs. Private school children and teachers can also participate in the program. In grants under this chapter, the Secretary ensures equitable participation of private school students and teachers, including in professional development programs. The term 'gifted and talented' is defined under applicable State law or by the State educational agency or local educational agency if the State does not have a specific law defining it. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Authorization of Appropriations for the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program is set at $170,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2010. $7,500,000 is allocated for Chapter A, with the remainder for Chapter 2. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. In the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program, amendments are made to various sections by replacing "part" with "chapter" and redesignating subsections.
